column4: Hi, I'm trying to make a copy of a .conf file before I mess with it on my server.  I'm using this command: sudo cp /etc/apt/apt.conf /etc/apt/apt.conf.original sudo chmod a-w /etc/apt/apt.conf.original.
I get the error: target '/etc/apt/apt.conf.original' is not a directory.  What am I doing wrong?
do this: cd /etc/apt/apt.conf;sudo cp apt.conf apt.conf.original
i meant this: cd /etc/apt;sudo cp apt.conf apt.conf.original
that should put a copy of the original in your home directory
that's why we love computers -- when they mess up, it's our fault :)
there's no real topic on saving conf files -- you need to know about "linux file permissions" & the "cp" command.
do this: "sudo vi /etc/apt/apt.conf.d" then type ":w /etc/apt/apt.conf.d" then type ":q"
do this: "sudo vi /etc/apt/apt.conf.d" then type ":w /etc/apt/apt.conf.d.original" then type ":q"
it might not be a file
the "-r" means recursive, you need this to copy a directory.
Okie dokie. I was trying to copy a directory. Epic fail. But now I've got the CORRECT conf files copied.  Thanks to all!
